title: Vaccines, Travel: Drug Class, Uses, Side Effects, Drug Names
author: Medical Reviewer Sarfaroj Khan; BHMS; PGD Health Operations
description: Travel vaccines are vaccines administered to provide protection against certain bacterial and viral infections for travelers. Learn about how they work, usages, side effects, and a list of drugs.
cleaned_text: How do travel vaccines work? Travel [vaccines](https://www.rxlist.com/vaccines/definition.htm) are vaccines administered to protect against certain [bacterial](https://www.rxlist.com/bacterial/definition.htm) and [viral](https://www.rxlist.com/viral/definition.htm) infections for travelers to places with [endemic](https://www.rxlist.com/endemic/definition.htm) infectious diseases. Vaccines stimulate the [immune system](https://www.rxlist.com/immune_system/definition.htm) to produce antibodies against specific types of [bacteria](https://www.rxlist.com/bacteria/definition.htm) and [viruses](https://www.rxlist.com/viruses/definition.htm) from which the vaccines are derived. Travel vaccines include both viral and bacterial vaccines which may be live or inactivated. Live vaccines are weakened forms of the actual viruses or bacteria and provide strong and often life-long [immunity](https://www.rxlist.com/immunity/definition.htm) similar to a natural [infection](https://www.rxlist.com/infection/definition.htm), but may not be safe for persons with compromised [immune](https://www.rxlist.com/immune/definition.htm) systems. Inactivated vaccines are made from [proteins](https://www.rxlist.com/proteins/definition.htm) or fragments of the [disease](https://www.rxlist.com/disease/definition.htm)-causing germs, but killed to prevent [replication](https://www.rxlist.com/replication/definition.htm). Inactivated vaccines contain the bacterial or viral [antigen](https://www.rxlist.com/antigen/definition.htm) which stimulates the production of antibodies without the risk of the disease itself, but may not produce as strong immunity as live vaccines do. Travel vaccines protect against the following infectious diseases: [Hepatitis A](https://www.rxlist.com/hepatitis_a/definition.htm)and [B virus](https://www.rxlist.com/b_virus/definition.htm)infections, bacteria serogroups A, C, Y and W-135 [Polio](https://www.rxlist.com/polio/definition.htm)( [poliomyelitis](https://www.rxlist.com/poliomyelitis/definition.htm)), a disabling disease caused by [poliovirus](https://www.rxlist.com/poliovirus/definition.htm) [Rabies](https://www.rxlist.com/rabies/definition.htm), caused by the rabies [virus](https://www.rxlist.com/virus/definition.htm)that is transmitted when bitten or scratched by rabid animals [Typhoid fever](https://www.rxlist.com/typhoid_fever/definition.htm), caused by [Salmonella](https://www.rxlist.com/salmonella/definition.htm)typhi [Yellow fever](https://www.rxlist.com/yellow_fever/definition.htm), a disease spread by mosquitoes, affects the liver How are travel vaccines used? Travel vaccines may be administered as [prophylaxis](https://www.rxlist.com/prophylaxis/definition.htm) before traveling to disease-endemic areas as: [Oral](https://www.rxlist.com/oral/definition.htm)capsules [Intramuscular](https://www.rxlist.com/intramuscular_im/definition.htm)(IM) injections the into the [tissue](https://www.rxlist.com/tissue/definition.htm)under the [skin](https://www.rxlist.com/skin/definition.htm) The [FDA](https://www.rxlist.com/fda/definition.htm)-approved travel vaccines include the following: [Hepatitis](https://www.rxlist.com/hepatitis/definition.htm)A inactivated viral vaccine for adults and children - Hepatitis A and B inactivated viral vaccine for adults - Meningococcal A, C, Y, and W-135 inactivated bacterial vaccine for 2 years and older individuals - Poliovirus inactivated viral vaccine for adults and children - Rabies inactivated viral vaccine for adults and children [Typhoid](https://www.rxlist.com/typhoid/definition.htm) [fever](https://www.rxlist.com/fever/definition.htm)live bacterial vaccine for adults and children - Yellow fever live bacterial vaccine for adults and children What are side effects of travel vaccines? Side effects of travel vaccines may include the following: - Injection site reactions include: [Erythema](https://www.rxlist.com/erythema/definition.htm)(redness) - Tenderness Convulsions/seizures [Upper respiratory [alanine aminotransferase](https://www.rxlist.com/alanine_aminotransferase_alt/definition.htm)( [ALT](https://www.rxlist.com/alt_alanine_aminotransferase/definition.htm)) Information contained herein is not intended to cover all possible side effects, precautions, warnings, drug interactions, allergic reactions, or adverse effects. Check with your [doctor](https://www.rxlist.com/doctor/definition.htm) or [pharmacist](https://www.rxlist.com/pharmacist/definition.htm) to make sure these drugs do not cause any harm when you take them along with travel medicines. Never stop taking your [medication](https://www.rxlist.com/medication/definition.htm) and never change your dose or frequency without consulting your doctor. What are names of travel vaccines? [Generic](https://www.rxlist.com/generic/definition.htm) and brand names of travel vaccines include: [Havrix](https://www.rxlist.com/havrix-drug.htm) - HDCV - hepatitis A vaccine [Imovax](https://www.rxlist.com/imovax-drug.htm)Rabies [IPOL](https://www.rxlist.com/ipol-drug.htm) and vaccine - meningococcal A C Y and [yellow fever vaccine](https://www.rxlist.com/consumer_yellow_fever_vaccine_yf_vax/drugs-condition.htm) - YF Vax
